title: 106_hr1829
content: The Air Force plays a role in managing the Civil Air Patrol as a civilian auxiliary of the Air Force. The Civil Air Patrol, as a federally chartered corporation and volunteer civilian auxiliary of the Air Force, is administered by the Chief of Staff of the Air Force under the direction of the Secretary of the Air Force. The Civil Air Patrol is administered by the Chief of Staff of the Air Force under the direction of the Secretary of the Air Force. The organization has a National Board of Directors appointed by the Secretary of the Air Force, consisting of Air Force general officers, senior civilian employees, and members from the Civil Air Patrol membership. The National Board of Directors for the Civil Air Patrol includes senior civilian employees of the Department of the Air Force and members appointed from the volunteer Civil Air Patrol membership. The chairman of the Board is the senior active duty Air Force officer, and the Board appoints a National Commander and an Executive Director for the Civil Air Patrol. The National Board of Directors for the Civil Air Patrol appoints a National Commander, Executive Director, Safety Officer, and Inspector General. These positions report directly to the Secretary of the Air Force through the National Board of Directors. The Chief of Staff of the Air Force can assign Air Force officers, enlisted members, and civilian employees to serve at the national headquarters of the Civil Air Patrol. The National Board of Directors appoints key positions in the Civil Air Patrol, who report to the Secretary of the Air Force. Air Force members and civilian employees can be appointed to management positions in the Civil Air Patrol without receiving compensation. The Executive Director and National Board of Directors of the Civil Air Patrol may utilize employees and volunteer members as needed to administer the organization and support the Air Force's noncombat mission, without additional compensation beyond regular military pay. The Civil Air Patrol is administered to support the Air Force's noncombat mission. Members and employees are not considered Federal employees and are exempt from laws governing Federal employment. The Civil Air Patrol members and employees are not considered Federal employees and are exempt from civil statutes and regulations. The Secretary of the Air Force can still set standards of conduct for them. Funds provided to the Civil Air Patrol are subject to financial regulations. The Civil Air Patrol's powers, including adopting a constitution, are subject to approval by the Secretary of the Air Force. A clerical amendment was made to the table of sections in the chapter. The Civil Air Patrol's powers are subject to approval by the Secretary of the Air Force. Air Force role in management and assistance by other agencies are highlighted.
